• n, I ought to have viſited you firſt, in re
• ard I am very much obliged unto you: • ut to proceed no farther in ceremony, let • s diſcourſe of ſome other affaires. I will • e bold to enquire, how all our friends doe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, Some of them have undergone change • f fortunes, and therein declared an invincible • rength of mind; but Heaven be thanked, all • hat honour and reſpect you, are living, and in • ealth.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p:
Sir, I am wonderfull glad to heare of it, • nd I ſhall rejoyce exceedingly when I • eete any of my old acquaintance; I hope I
am not altogether loſt unto their remembrance, they will know me certainely.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir. Travell hath not wrought much change in you, but I detaine you, I feare, from your reſt.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir, Were I tired with travell, as I am not, yet your company would very much refreſh me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I will crave your pardon at this time, I know to tarry longer, would be troubleſome unto you; but to morrow I will wayte on you againe.

div.head: To entertaine a friend, who is come to viſit one.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I Am moſt glad to ſee you, though I have no other entertainement for you, but a kind welcome.

sp.speaker: Aymwell.
sp.p:
Sir, I expect no more, I come to enioy your
company, and to be happy in your ſociety; for in the generall, I doe find none that can ſuite my condition, ſo well as your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, Take of me what pleaſes you, I am vowed to your ſervice; and your loving viſitation is an addition to your many other kindneſſes.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir. All that I acknowledge, is a will to doe you ſervice: but I haue beene ſlow in producing the effects, hereafter I will ſtudy to deſerve.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, it is your ingenuous goodneſſe, to decline the acknowledgement of your owne vertue and deſerts, farre ſurpaſſing my merit; for tis I am bound to be your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir, It is I that am obliged to you, by many ſtrong tyes of affection, from which the ſervice of my life cannot diſengage mee; but I have treſpaſt againſt manners, pray take the chaire.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, Pleaſe you to ſit firſt, for it becomes me to waite your leaſure.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir, J am provided, but if it may not appeare too much boldneſſe, what was the Adamant, or occaſion, that made you thus kinde, to viſit my lodging?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, Shall I tell you? I came not to borrow mony, or to enforce your good nature to grant any motion of requeſt; but only to keep our love and amity freſh, and in perfect ſtrength, by ſome conference.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir, You have choſen a bad opportunity, my affaires carry me away from my friends; beſides the obligation of my word to a Lady, to attend upon her this day.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I will chooſe ſome other time, to attend you.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir. J will attend upon you, if J might know the place, and houre, where to meete you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I will not put you to that trouble, it will become mee rather to waite on you.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir, Pardon me, I am much obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I am your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir, I am the ſervant of your ſervants, pray remember my reſpects to all our friends.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I will be yours in that, and all other ſervices.

div.head: To woe a faire young Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Aymwell.
sp.p: PArdon me, I pray, if I preſume to ſpeake, what I have hitherto, with much affliction, hid from your knowledge.

There is a Gentleman that hath beheld your outward beauty, and by his judgement clearely diſcerned your vertues, the ornament of your mind; theſe have produc'd in him a ſtrange effect, ſo that in ſpite of his owne Reaſon, or diſſwaſion of friends, he is violently compell'd to ſpeake truth.

sp.speaker: Penelope.
sp.p: Sir, Call you this an affliction? Tis unhappineſſe to ſpeake, and heare truth.

sp.speaker: Aymwell,
sp.p:
Doe you hold that opinion?
Then I will convince you by your owne argument. For if it be unhappineſſe to heare truth; then I hope you will pardon me, if being compelled by the ſtrength of my paſſion, I doe truly tell you, that J have plac'd my affection wholly upon you, or as they commonly ſay, J doe love you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Sir, I am ſorry that you have made mee the obiect of your love, I know your birth and perſon may deſerve one of greater account; and therefore I am amazed at the unexpreſſed novelty of your motion, not imagining, but your boſome had been free from any flame: let your wiſdom then ſuppreſſe it, leaſt your love becom fruitleſſe in the event.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I will not be diſcouraged by your firſt anſwer, for neither are you beneath me in quality, who am your ſervant; neither can it appeare to you ſo ſtrange a matter, that I ſhould be taken with your beauty, which others admire; though it be my fortune only, to be bolder then the reſt, and I hope not unwelcome.

sp.speaker: Penelope.
sp.p:
Sir, I would not have you cheriſh any uncertaine hope, nor build any aſſured foundation, where you have no ground given: love cannot be compelled, but muſt flow from
the ſpring of naturall deſire; but I find in my ſelfe no inclination to entertaine your affection; therefore you muſt pardon me, if I deny your ſute, which I cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Nothing is impoſſible to love; for if you would beleeve that I beare a noble and conſtant affection towards you, you would ſoone overcome this difficulty, and encline your minde to reward my affection with your favour.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Sir, I am confident, that your affection is right and perfect, not ſeeking, under a faire and colourable pretence, to betray me: yet I cannot force my ſelfe to conſent to your motion, I being utterly ignorant in Love matters; therefore excuſe me, till time, and conſideration ſhall enforce me how to anſwer your deſire.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I am comforted, that you have not utterly denied my ſute; I hope at my next viſitation to receive more comfort; till then, I take my leave, and preſume onely to breath my heart upon your hand, or, if you pleaſe, your lip, deſiring you to remember me in abſence.

div.head: When one meeteth a friend in the Streete.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: GOD ſave you, Sir, You are moſt happily met. How fare you?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Sir, I am the better to ſee you well and luſtie, why will you not doe me the honour to viſit me at my Chamber?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt confeſſe I have often broken promiſe therein, but buſineſſe would not permit me, otherwiſe I had long ſince waited on you.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhould rather account my ſelfe obliged to waite on you, for I am bound unto you for many favours; eſpecially, for the laſt courteſie you did me in a matter which concerned me much. Will you now doe me the kindneſſe to beare my reſpects to a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, If ſhe be honeſt, I am ready to goe on your errand. I hope you will not put me on a diſgracefull peece of ſervice.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you have no ſuch bad ſuſpition of me, for ſhe is both a faire and vertuous Gentlewoman, and hath a nimble wet: but I know you can deliver your mind in an excellent way.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, It is you, whom Mercury the god of wit hath adorn'd with a gentle amorous ſpeech; but I will ſpeake in your behalfe, in as good and effectuall tearmes as I can remember.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Sir, You ſhall doe me then a moſt perfect favour. Tell her, I am her ready and willing ſervant, and that the power of love hath given her my heart, which I will come to fetch, in hope ſhe will give it me backe, and till then keepe it warme in her owne boſome. But what need I inſtruct you, who are all Love and Courtſhip?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I will performe your command, though not in ſuch words, as you would deſire, yet ſo as my ſuddaine Genius ſhall prompt me, but I have heard it ſaid.

q.l: That in way of love and glory,
Lovers best tell their owne ſtory.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Sir, Pardon me, J know whom I doe entruſt with this buſineſſe, I am aſſur'd of your fidelity, and that you can deliver your mind in a powerfull maner, eſpecially, to Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, It muſt be my love to you that muſt inſpire me: but I promiſe you, I will ſtrive to ſpeake my beſt.

Sir, I am confident in you, and at your returne
from my Miſtris, I will prepare thankes for this great peece of ſervice, and reſt, yours obliged.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Sir, It is but my duty, I am happy to be imployed in any ſervice that concernes you, ſuppoſe this done.

div.head: To court a Gentlewoman in the way of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Eugenius.
sp.p: MIſtreſſe, I doubt not but that you will judge me as raſh as bould: but I beſeech your divine beautie which glittereth in your faire eyes, to excuſe my audacity, and to pardon my temeritie, which have emboldened mee to come and preſent unto you my most humble and moſt affectionate ſervice.

p.hi: Sir, I am very ſorry that I have not the honour to know you: and I mervaile that you will offer ſervice to mee, that of all am moſt unworthy.

sp.speaker: Eugenius.
sp.p: Miſtris, It is the ſweetneſſe of your naturall goodneſſe that cauſeth you to ſpeake in this ſort.

sp.speaker: Calia.
sp.p: Pardon mee Sir, I ſpeake nothing but I know to be moſt true.

sp.speaker: Eugenius.
sp.p: Lady, This ſingular modeſtie which I ſee to the life expreſſed in your words, gives me a hope that you will entertaine my intentions not as harſh and diſconſonant, but as agreeable and conſonant, and that in time I ſhall obtaine ſome one of your favours and graces.

p.hi: Sir, if there were any graces in me, they were yours: but I have not any, you can expect none.

sp.speaker: Eugenius.
sp.p:
Miſtris, It is that, which obligeth mee to a greater estimation of you, and makes you more amiable, and mee more affectionate towards you: ſo alſo J beſeech you to beleeve that my intentions were never otherwiſe than chaſt and vertuous, and that I never had any other end than honeſty. Did you thinke me to have framed ſome deſigne prejudicious to
your honours. J had rather looſe my being, than entertaine any ſuch thought: ſo alſo is it my reſolution for ever to continue your moſt faithfull and obedient ſervant, as the effects ſhall make it evident that the proofe thereof ſhall manifeſtly appeare whenſoever your commands ſhall call upon me.

sp.speaker: Calia,
sp.p: I humbly thank you Sir with my beſt affection; as alſo for the paines you have taken for one that no way merits ſuch favours, I being your very humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Eugenius.
sp.p: Lady, It is I that am ſo deepely engaged to you, that I am diſenabled to quit my ſelfe of the obligation, and therefore (moſt faire Miſtreſſe) I beſeech and conjure you to make uſe of my ſervice and me, in whatſoever you ſhall judge me capable to ſerve you. And in the meane time after a million of recommendations J will be bold to take my leave of you, and will leave my heart with you as an aſtage and pledge of my fidelity and conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Calia.
sp.p: Farwell Sir, and I give you humble thankes for this your loving viſit.

sp.speaker: Eugenius,
sp.p: I hope to ſee you againe and very ſpeedily, where for the preſent I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Calia.
sp.p: Sir, So farre as your intentions ſhall continue good, and your ſuits lawfull, you ſhall alwayes finde our dores open, and alſo to Gentlemen like your ſelfe, who ſhall not want our beſt entertainement according to our beſt poſſibility, and in that regard you ſhall no oftner come then be welcome.

sp.speaker: Eugenius.
sp.p: Lady, J do aſſure you that I now goe to elongate my ſelfe from my bright day, and confine my ſelfe into an abiſſe of melancholy darkneſſe: for I dare be bold to proteſt unto you, that without you, I enjoy no light of day, and therefore all the time of this ſad abſence will be ſo tedious to mee, that moments will bee houres, the houres dayes, and the dayes will be ages, unleſſe it be ſo that the experience of being in your favour will be my ſole conſolation, and with that I will arme my ſelfe with a reſolute patience.

sp.speaker: Calia.
sp.p: You ſpeake ſtrong lines Sir, but it may be you are not ſo paſſionate as your words pretend. Farewell Sir, till our next meeting:

sp.speaker: Eugenius.
sp.p: Miſtris, you doe a wrong to your beauty, and to my love which is faithfull and loyall: but I hope that time will make me appear more largely to be what I am, and ſeeing neceſſity conſtraines me to retire from you, J will never retreat from my affection which your faire eyes have darted into my ſoule. And ſo Lady adieu till my next review, which I aſſure you ſhall be my ſooneſt poſſible.

div.head: To preſent ſomthing to a friend.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: SIR, I have alwayes had an earneſt deſire to make my ſervice viſible unto you, and therefore I am bold to preſent unto you this Ring; deſiring you, not to value the gift, but the affection of the giver, who doth ſacrifice this unto you, from the Altar of an humble heart.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, This is an addition to your many other favours, you are mindfull of me above my merit; how ſhall I make you requitall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, Your acceptance thereof is the chiefe ayme of my deſires; I would have you thinke, that true love uſes by dumbe ſignes and tokens to expreſſe it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Sir, Beleeve mee, ſo rich a gift as this
hath a moſt powerfull language: if it had been meaner, it would have ſufficed me, who muſt reſt beholding unto you, till I have opportunity to declare my ſelfe farther.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, It is your worthines that makes it appeare ſo worthy: but I know no gift can be above your merit, nor ſufficient to declare in what ties of obſervance I am bound unto you: your acceptation gives it more luſtre and richneſſe then the Ring doth deſerve, being but a meane token of my affection.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, J beſeech you doe not extenuate your ſelfe, nor it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, This Ring is but the embleme of my ſervice, which ſince you are pleaſed to receive, I muſt give you many thankes for your acceptance.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, Jt is eaſie to perſwade the receit of a thing of ſuch value, but I will merit it as the oblation of my love.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, For that I muſt remaine eternally your conſtant, faithfull friend.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, I am yours in all reſpectfull ſervices, to be commanded.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, You oblige me too much both in words and deeds, I am all yours.

div.head: To entreate a courteſie of a friend.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: SIr, as neceſſity hath no law, ſo it hath no ſhame; for, contrary to my diſpoſition, I muſt become an importunate Suter unto you.

p.hi: Sir, Name it, it muſt be ſomething more then I know of, which I can deny you, who are alwayes modeſt in your requeſts.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, I feare I ſhall give you no occaſion to report the contrary, I would deſire you to lend me your Horſe, to cary away a little treaſure by Mooneſhine.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, I doe not well underſtand you, pray interpret your ſelfe, and diſguiſe not your meaning.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, I would deſire you to diſpenſe with mee, it is a matter that concernes me neare, I am to beare away the Vſurers Daughter, and cary her where ſhee ſhall remaine private, till ſtormes be blown over; pardon me, that I have made you acquainted with my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Sir, J will be ready to aſſiſt you, and
ſince your fortune cannot proceed without my Horſes legges, if he were the Muſes Pegaſus he ſhall be your ſervant, it is but to cary away a peece of live Veniſon, and that's a meane treſpaſſe; Cupid has enough in his Parke.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Sir, I am glad you are ſo pleaſant, and doe ſo well apprehend my intents. I was afraid, leaſt my purpoſe being knowne, which was manifeſt in mee to deliver, I ſhould have ſuffered repulſe, and have beene blamed by you for my bold attempt.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No, Sir, I doe account it in you a bravery of minde, that dare aſpire to reach a fortune, and plucke the golden Apples of Heſperides, watch't by the old Dragon the Ʋſurer: but I would not have you loſe time in talke; I will bid the groome prepare my horſe ready for your employment.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, The whole ſervice of my life cannot requite your kindnes, for ſince you have granted this requeſt ſo willingly, I ſhall owe my good fortune to your favourable aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Sir, I will pray that your attempt may be proſperous, for I ſhall rejoyce in your happineſſe, as much as in mine owne; Therefore my good wiſhes ſhall bee your good Genius, to waite on
you; while my Prayers ſolicite heaven, for your happy ſucceſſe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, You have expreſt your ſelfe a noble friend; and when this buſineſſe is paſt, all the ſtudy of my life ſhall be to ſhew my thankfulneſſe to you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire nothing, but that you may thrive in your deſires.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sir, Next my intended purpoſe, my chiefeſt glory and ambition is, to thrive in your favour.

sp.speaker: EVgenius,
sp.p: I proteſt to you my faireſt, that I could never have beleeved that the torments of happines from our loves could have been ſo miſerable; for I dare ſweare to thee by thoſe faire eyes the ſtarres of my fortunes, that I dwelt with impatiency and ſorrowes till I ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.p: Is it poſſible Sir? ſurely I can hardly believe it.

sp.speaker: Eugenius,
sp.p:
Miſtris I beſeech you to beleeve
it if you pleaſe, for I aſſure you that I could no longer endure nor ſupport the violence and troubleſome tediouſnes which I indured in the time of your ſo long abſence, the object of my good and ſole content being removed.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.p: Sir, It may very well be, for you ſeeme very paſſionate in your actions.

sp.speaker: Eugenius,
sp.p: I proteſt that it is unpoſſible for me to take any complacency in the world, but in that only that flatters my affection, and in the aſpect of your rare forme and moſt excellent Beauty.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.p: Sir, It pleaſeth you to terme it ſo; content your ſelfe in laughing at mee, as you may at one that injoyeth not the leaſt glimpſe of beauty in my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Eugenius,
sp.p:
Wherein my deereſt, ſhould you conceive ſo of me? J doe aſſure you with the better part of my ſoule, that I ſhould be a miſerable man, ſhould I not really ſpeake what my affections ſuggeſt as truth: know LADIE, that you ſee a man that is wholy yours, and deſires not to live but for you, and to doe you ſervice: but that which troubleth mee moſt
is that of neceſſity I muſt abſent my ſelfe from you upon a very urgent occaſion, but I beſeech you to beleeve and conceive ſo of me that whither ſoever J goe, I ſhall carry with mee the lively delineaments of your perfections, and that I ſhall not live but by the Idea of your beauty with perfect reſolution of obeying you, and therfore my ſweeteſt adieu for a while, for the preſent to have mee excuſed that I cannot injoy the felicity of your moſt deſired company, but must take my leave ſo abruptly.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Sir, I infinitely thanke you, and bid you alſo adieu, wiſhing you a ſafe returne.

div.head: A merry Diſcourſe between Rowland and Suſan, ſitting up late together.

sp.speaker: ROw.
sp.p: It is time, Suſan, that I ſhould now diſcover my minde unto you, we have beene long ſervants together, and ever ſince my firſt comming, I have borne you good will, which I would deſire you to accept, and grant me your love.

p.hi:
For that you muſt pardon me, for J doe not intend to marry, and therefore let that
ſerve for an excuſe, ſince I would be loth to diſcourage you, and ſay, I cannot love you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: I hope you will not, for ſince I firſt beheld you, I have admired your perfections.

p.hi: You know, affection cannot be compel'd; therefore I thanke you for the good will which you have hitherto borne me, but as for your love, I cannot accept of it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Then I perceive you love ſome other.

p.hi: I deſire you to excuſe me, I cannot frame my minde to fancy you, though I know you deſerve my betters; but for mee to ſettle affection where I cannot love, would bee an endleſſe miſery: the Bryer and Honey-ſuckle cannot well agree.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Then you compare me to a Bryer, but I will with all humility put up your diſdaine, hoping that the continuance of my love ſhall ſoften your mind, to receive me into ſome degree of favour, for I proteſt, I love you entirely.

p.hi: The utmoſt I can doe for you in requitall of your love, is, to give you thankes, and counſell to ſuppreſſe your deſire, and not to proceed any farther in this ſute, which at last will become fruitleſſe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I ſhould be ſorry then: by this kiſſe which I preſume to take, none hath power over me but your ſelfe, I love you all over, and if you would licence my heart to ſtray about, how happy ſhould I be?

p.hi: Nay, then I perceive your love is but a raſh and wanton deſire; neither can I ſtay with you any longer, leaſt my abſence out of my Mistreſſes Chamber might breed ſome ſuſpition.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Stay, I will hold you in the priſon of my armes, and if you will get your freedome, you ſhal yeeld me ſome of your ſweeteſt kiſſes, which are but ſhaddowes of that ſubſtantiall happineſſe which you could afford me.

p.hi: Nay, pray be not rude, nor give mee cauſe to ſuſpect that your love is diſhoneſt, I had formerly better opinion of you, but now I am jealous of your good intent.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Pardon mee, if love have made me offend in ſome boyſterous actions.

p.hi: Come pray let me be gone, I ſhall be angry if you hinder me.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Well then, I obey your deſire, but let me prevaile farther with you at our next meeting.

div.head: An Enterchange of Ceremonies at parting with a friend taking a long journey.
div.p: SIr, I am very ſorry that my affaires doe compell me to take my leave of you, from whom I have received ſo many benefits, which have bound me in many tyes ever to ſerve you, neither have I any way left to ſatisfie my ſelfe in requiting your former kindneſſes, but to acknowledge them farre above my requitall, and to deſire you, that you would both receive the tender of my humble ſervice, and command me in ſomething, whereby I might expreſſe how much I honour your deſert.

Sir, I cannot chooſe but grieve that you must now bee divided from us, by a tedious journey; yet ſince he loves himſelfe better than his friend, that will not yeeld to any thing for his good, I am content in that regard to looſe your company a while, wiſhing you both a proſperous journey, and that in your abſence you would remember me, who will alwayes in my daily prayers ſollicite heaven for your ſafe returne, deſiring
to be excuſed for your poore entertainment, which perhaps makes you deſirous to be gone.
Sir, Pardon me, the entertainment I have found, was farre above my deſert, for which I render you a million of thankes. There remaines nothing now, but that you honour me with your commands.
Sir, I intreate you make not ſo great haſte to be gone.
Sir, I could willingly defer my journey, to enjoy your company; but the winde ſtands faire for France, therefore let us conclude all Ceremonies.
Sir, Since we muſt diſpenſe with your departure, I pray doe us the courteſie to revive our drooping mindes, with the good tydings of your ſafe arivall in France.
Sir, Be aſſur'd I cannot be unmindfull of you, nor of my other friends, to whom I pray you to commend mee, ſince I cannot take my leave of them all in particular.
Sir, J am glad you will doe mee the fauour to give me any imployment in your abſence, I will performe your deſire.

Sir, I can but thanke you, and for your love in bringing me to my Shippe, which is a trouble, that you would take upon you,
though on my part undeſerved.
Sir, I am happy to ſerve you in any thing, God ſend you a proſperous journey.
Sir, I doubt not but I ſhall arive in ſafetie, trouble your ſelfe no farther, ſince I cannot remaine with you to requite your kindneſſe.
Sir, Since you will needs have it ſo, I will bid you, farewell, with all the affection of a conſtant friend.

p.hi: PRay let mee prevaile ſo much with you, to entreate your company to dinner.

sp.speaker: Clorin.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly thanke you for your courteſie, but my buſineſſe will not permit; therefore I deſire to be excuſed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Nay good, Sir, Let me not be denyed, I muſt confeſſe indeed your cheare will not bee worthy of your ſtay; but you ſhall be heartily welcome.

sp.speaker: Clorin.
sp.p: Sir, I would willingly obey your deſire, but I feare to be too bold.

p.hi: Sir, You ſhall be moſt welcome; you ſhall command in my houſe as in your own.

sp.speaker: Clori.
sp.p: Your offer is ſo large and courteous, that I muſt yeeld to waite on you, for you have overcome me in ceremony; but you will draw upon your ſelfe much trouble.

p.hi: Sir, You will finde but courſe fare, but ſuch as it is, pray eſteeme your ſelfe moſt heartily welcome, and in a reall manner without complement.

sp.speaker: Clori.
sp.p: Sir, Here is much plenty, and you wrong your ſelfe to excuſe your fare, whereof there is ſo great abundance, that unleſſe you would have provided all the variety that was in Noah's Arke, I know not how it could be mended.

p.hi: It is your favour to commend and accept of any thing, but pray excuſe me, once more I deſire it: if I had beene certaine of your honouring my houſe with your preſence, I would have made better preparation for your entertainment.

sp.speaker: Clori.
sp.p:
Sir, I deſire you rather to excuſe my boldneſſe, in putting you to ſo much trouble, you may perceive that I thinke my ſelfe welcome by my liberall feeding: I am
no mincing Bride, whoſe thoughts of eating are tooke away with the conceite of the night following.

p.hi: I beſeech you ſpare not, J am glad to ſee you ſo pleaſant, and to increaſe your mirth, I will drinke to your health in wine, in hope you will pledge me.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Sir, They ſay there is truth in wine, and if there be truth in wine, I will finde it out, let the health bee nere ſo deepe.

p.hi: Thanke you for doing mee this peece of juſtice: pray ſee if you can make a homely Dinner, otherwiſe J know not how to be excuſed for inviting you.

sp.speaker: Clori.
sp.p: Sir, To decline ceremony, you have moſt worthily feaſted me, and honoured mee ſo much, that I muſt ever acknowledge your exceeding bountie and courteſie.

div.head: Ceremonies at ſitting downe at the Table.

sp.speaker: Alexander.
sp.p: GEntlemen, Pray take your places, I know not how to direct you. But firſt let us waſh.

p.hi: Pray begin, for it is fit that we ſhould follow you.

sp.speaker: Alexander.
sp.p: In this matter, Ceremonies are needleſſe; but you will doe nothing without my example, and therefore I will begin.

p.hi: Then in obedience to your deſire, we will waſh with you.

sp.speaker: Alexander.
sp.p: I beſeech you Gentlemen, to ſave me a labour, and take your places.

sp.speaker: Gentlemen.
sp.p: Sir, Wee expect your ſitting downe, and afterwards, we will not contend much for prioritie of place.

sp.speaker: Alexander.
sp.p: Come, M. Getting, you are my old acquaintance, you ſhall favour me to ſit here by me.

p.hi: By no meanes, that is not my place, heres a Gentleman deſerves to be ſeated there.

sp.speaker: Alexander.
sp.p: Sir, I have deſigned you this place, pray let me rule ſo farre.

p.hi: Sir, J ſhould bee loth to be too troubleſome, and yet J would not preſume before my betters.

sp.speaker: Alexander.
sp.p: Sir, You are too full of excuſe, you may yeeld to take your due place, otherwiſe I ſhould wrong you.

p.hi: Sir, I beſeech you then to excuſe me, and account it your fault, if J tranſgreſſe the bounds of manners, in aſſuming a place farre above my deſert, and which is of right belonging to theſe other Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Alexander.
sp.p:
We might have ſpar'd this ceremony, for the appetite loves good dainties better than Complements Now pray ſerve your ſelves,
you are kindely welcome.

sp.speaker: Gentlemen.
sp.p: Sir, Wee will not put you to any trouble in helping us, we know that manners will allow us to make a dinner, we come to treſpaſſe on you.

div.head: The Feaſters excuſe to his friend, after dinner.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire you to excuſe your meane fare, and ſlender entertainement, whereunto I have preſumed much to invite you; but I hope our ancient acquaintance, and your owne good nature will procure me a pardon, in that I have done this only to enjoy your company and ſociety, for your good diſcourſe is to me a feaſt, farre exceeding any fare that I could provide for you.

p.hi: Your reall kindnes hath bin ſuch and ſo unexpected, that I cannot give you ſufficient thankes for your courteſie and kinde entertainment: all that I can render, is to promiſe, that I will ſnatch an opportunity to expreſſe my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
You have honoured me enough, in
your acceptance of my good will. But it is not good to ſtir ſuddenly after dinner. Let's talke, you are converſant abroad, what newes doe you heare?

sp.speaker: Friend,
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, the world runs about mee while I ſtand unmov'd, never marking the motion thereof, and therefore I am altogether ignorant in Novelties, it may be you heare more.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I have ſo many affaires, that I can enquire after none, I thought you could have given us ſome good intelligence.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire you to excuſe me, for I hold it a fruitleſſe imployment, but yet to ſatisfie your requeſt, if I knew any freſh newes, that were not yet in print, J will be bold to tell you ſomewhat, ſince you deſire it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I will not importune you any farther, but deſire your pardon, that I ſhould impoſe on you the office of a Taleteller: excuſe my intent therein, ſince what I deſire, was to paſſe away the time while we ſit: but now, if you pleaſe, we will riſe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sir, Then I muſt really thanke you, you have made me bold with you, J will accompany you a while to the fire, and then take my leave.

div.head: To offer ſervice to a young Maid.

p.hi: Seeing you are alone, I would offer you to attend on you, if you would accept of my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: It is more than J deſire, or deſerve; and it would appeare boldneſſe in me to accept of a ſtrangers company.

p.hi: It is not for me to accept all ſhewes and offers of kindneſſe, I can but thanke you for your good will, I am not farre diſtant from my owne home.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Pray let me beare you company, and by the way make me happie in ſome diſcourſe, reſolve mee one queſtion; Were you never in love?

p.hi: Though it be no manners to anſwer one queſtion, with demanding another; yet I will preſume to aske you, If you were never in love?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p:
Faire one, from thence ſprings my unhappineſſe, I am too forward in theſe deſires, J have beheld many beauties, but you have prevailed more than the reſt, to conquer my affection;
and I muſt acknowledge, that in meeting you, I have met death, or life.

p.hi: Pray ſpeake in plaine tearmes, I am ignorant of your meaning.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I deſire you then to know and beleeve, that I am already farre in love with you, and I hope you will not ſcorne my ſuddaine motion, if I ſhould deſire you to reward my love with your favour; and by the way, let me entreate you, to thinke that heaven had appointed our ſtrange accidentall meeting and gave mee boldneſſe to petition your favour and affection, which I hope you will grant.

p.hi: Sir I know not in this caſe how to give an anſwer, that may procure your content, but I deſire you importune mee no farther, but grant me time to conſider your motion, this is my Fathers houſe, whither, if pleaſe you to come hereafter, I will ſtudy to reſolve you, howſoever you ſhall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: But before I loſe your preſence, which is my chiefe happineſſe, let me tell you, that when you goe in, you beare away my heart with you, and I ſhall onely languiſh in ſorrow, tell I viſit you againe.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p:
Pray, Sir, doe not hold me longer
in diſcourſe, there are many jealous eyes that doe watch an occaſion to make me cenſured for maintaining with you ſuch unuſuall familiaritie; pray, as you tender my credit, leave me.

p.hi: I muſt obey, honour me with an ordinary ſalutation, and I will vaniſh like a ſhadow, that will returne again to wait on you, who are the ſubſtance of my life.

div.head: To confer with a Widdow in an amorous wooing manner.

sp.speaker: AYm.
sp.p: I would entreate you (faire Widdow) not to diſcourage mee in my firſt ſute, ſince your modeſty and vertuous cariage in your Husbands life time, hath made mee bold to plead for affection; and to cheriſh a certaine hope, that I ſhall obtaine my deſire.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.p:
Sir, I would not have you imagine, that my love to my former Huſband was written on a Table booke, the Letters whereof may bee ſoone wiped out againe; no, it was engraved upon my
heart, and there doth remaine to informe mee that I ought not to wrong him with a ſecond marriage.

sp.speaker: Aymwell.
sp.p: Nay, Widdow, I muſt acknowledge you have a faire pretence to put mee off, with the remembrance of your ſaid Huſband, but will you alwayes puniſh your ſelfe, and faſt from the joyes of marriage?

p.hi: It is my full reſolved purpoſe, and therefore let not any wanton opinion concerning me, give you hope of obtaining my love; Alas! Since his departure, I am dead unto the world, and doe but only live, to ſigh, when I remember that I had ſo good a Husband.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: His goodneſſe is gone with him, but for my part, I will be your living active ſervant; come, come, put off griefe and falſe imaginations of honouring the dead, for if his ſoule were capable of any knowledge, concerning earthlie matters, it would rejoyce to ſee you happily married, and as hee gave you all contentment in his l fe time, ſo he would deſire that you might bee ſupplyed in the ſame kinde after his death.

p.hi: You ſpeake unhappily, but pray be ſatisfied that I intend not to marry, yet I reſpect your good will, and other matters will remaine ready to requite your love.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: For other matters I am ſatisfied, but your love is the mark whereat I aime, why ſhould you thus ſtrive to become a virgin againe, and forget the conceit of former pleaſures, which are yet freſh in your remembrance; fie, fie, you doe not well to make your ſelfe ſo dull of apprehenſion, I am come to offer ſervice in the right kind, and therfore you are very much too blame, to refuſe the tender of my labour.

p.hi: You ſpeake myſteries; but I deſire if you love me, ſhew it in ceaſing to proſecute your ſute; for I muſt tell you plainly, it will prove fruitleſſe, and of none effect.

sp.speaker: Aymwell,
sp.p: I cannot beleeve, but that I ſhall bee more fortunately happy to obtaine your favour; words are not alwaies the interpreters of the heart, and I am confident, for all this, that you love me.

p.hi: Perſwade your ſelfe to it, but I ſhall never give you cauſe to thinke ſo, yet I will ever reſpect you, and be ready to doe you any uſuall courteſie.

sp.speaker: Aymwell,
sp.p:
Well I thanke you that I have
ſo farre thrived in my ſute; I hope hereafter to get deeper into your favour.

p.hi: Your hope is built upon a falſe foundation, and had I knowne your intent, I would not have held diſcourſe with you ſo long; I muſt leave your company.

sp.speaker: Aymwell,
sp.p: Let me rather take my leave of you, and ſeale a kiſſe upon your lippe untill I viſit you again, for no mortall Widdow ſhall diſcourage me, but I will come again about that buſines.

div.head: To excuſe ſome offence to a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: AYmwell,
sp.p: I muſt acknowledge I was ſomewhat too bold to enforce a kiſſe from you, in the preſence of other friends; but I pray excuſe my paſſion, and let your mercy be ſhewed in pardoning, as my folly was in offending.

p.hi: Sir, It was ſo great a treſpaſſe, and ſo directly aym'd againſt my white fame and reputation, that no repentance can ſatisfie for a fault of that nature.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p:
It cannot exceed the limits of forgiveneſſe, or if your wrath cannot be otherwiſe ſatisfied, enjoyne me ſome penance, as
great as your anger, whereby I may recover your loſt favour, and make it appeare, how ſorry I am for committing ſo raſh an offence.

p.hi: Nay, you may enjoy that kiſſe violently tooke from mee before ſo many witneſſes; but never any more.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I muſt confeſſe it was my raſhneſſe, but if you will that I repay it back againe, I will give you intereſt for that one, and vow unto you, never to offend your patience in the like kind.

p.hi: Well, ſince you are ſo willing to repent, and to ſhew unfained ſorrow, I muſt needs accept them for preſent ſatisfaction, deſiring you hereafter to be more carefull of my credit, and never againe to make ſo bold an offer.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You have charmed mee to obedience, ſince your words are a law, which I dare not tranſgreſſe, for I am in all things, your obedient ſervant.

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: ALas! Sir, is this the houre then, when the ſevere rigour of your abſence muſt eclipſe my dayes of their bright beames? Oh how this ſad newes doth fire my ſpirits! and not without reaſon, ſince you to whom I had wholly conſecrated my ſelfe, will not deigne a mercifull eye on my ſufferings for your abſence.

sp.speaker: Floreſtan.
sp.p: Miſtris, Feare not, but reſt aſſured, that ſo long as life will give mee leave to enjoy the Suns brightneſſe, never ſhall any other have power over me; doe me onely the favour, that having given you theſe new aſſurances of my fidelity, you will bee pleaſed to render mee ſome reall promiſes of yours. Beſides, I proteſt to you, Lady, I will never acknowledge any other light then yours, no more than the Earth doth other then the Suns.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Sir, They are no falſe promiſes that I have made you, but true aſſurances,
drawne from my heart by the force of my paſſion. And know, that all things here be neath ſhall ſooner change their naturall inclinations, then in me ſhall be ſeene any alteration from the reſolution I have made to love you: heaven it ſelfe ſhall be my witnes.

sp.speaker: Floreſtan:
sp.p: If Miſtris, you love mee thus, let your minde bee confident of an equall troth from mee; and ſhould you doubt of my affections, I will give you my ſoule for pledge, and my heart for ſacrifice, to ſhew you that my words are unfained, I pray you therefore accept of this ſmall gift, not as a thing worthie of merit, but onely as a ſufficient teſtimony of my good will, fidelity, and faithfull love towards you; and being a thing ſo ſmall and unworthy of you, it will therefore be the more commendable in you to accept of it.

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: Sir, I give you infinite thanks, and withall doe beſeech you alſo to receive this in requitall, for a remembrance of me, which is of ſmall value, but be mov'd to take it in good part from her, who from henceforth, ſhall not live but through your ſole remembrance.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Thanks to you, ſweeteſt, the gift truly is pleaſing to me, but the giver much more.

sp.speaker: Leoner.
sp.p: But, Sir, Is there, no meanes to ſtay you for a little time, that I might enjoy your preſence, which ſtands me in ſtead of light and life, therefore your abſence will envelope me with darkneſſe, and bring upon mee (poore ſoule that I am) a thouſand grievous deaths.

sp.speaker: Floreſt.
sp.p: Miſtris, I hope, not ſo, for I am conſtrained through neceſſitie of my buſineſse to depart hence.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, I ſee now too well, that that conſtancy of yours, which I truſted to for remedy of my troubled thoughts, is vaniſhed, to give preſent vent to my plaints, which you ſhall receive with my ſighs and teares for true and burning teſtimonies of the ſorrow I have to ſee my ſelfe about to be forſaken by him, by whom only I breath.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Miſtris, I ſweare to you, my heart is alike touch'd with ſuch ſtrokes for this our parting, that I can hardly breath for griefe of it, and doe already ſee I have loſt my eye ſight, in the loſse of the ſight of your Star-like beautie. For ſure I am, that once abſent from your luminous aſpect, each pleaſure will be to me a ſubject, of griefe and ſorrow. However, ſince • t will now be no otherwiſe, J ſhall ſo part with
you, as that my will ſhall never depart from your ſervice. Therefore farewell, deare Miſtris, live ſtill happie and content whilſt I languiſh, unhappie though conſtant: let not that my remoteneſſe alter your mind, no more than it ſhall ſhake the reſolution I have long ſince made to live and die yours; for, for mine owne part, I ſhall not thinke my ſelfe abſent from you, ſo long as I ſhall keep a room in your heart and memory.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Farewell, Sir, you poſſeſſe my ſoule; and I doe even leave it in your power conſerving it for a more happie ſeaſon then this of parting: in the meane ſpace, have pitty on all the bloudy griefes which the meere apprehenſion of your abſence makes me already feel ſo vehemently, for I think it very ſtrange to leave him, whoſe company is dearer to me then my life. But to make an end of this diſcourſe; I do beſeech you, Sir, and even conjure you, by the ſweetnes of that love I have borne you, and will all my life long devote to you, for my cruell feares, to write often to mee, during the unhappie time of your abſence: for in reading your Letters, I ſhall perſwade my ſelfe that I am not wholly deprived of you.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
I vow to you, Miſtris, I will give you ſo
many Letters, for confirmation of my loyaltie, and the love I beare you, that you ſhall have no cauſe to diſtruſt. And ſo J pray God to make you the happieſt alive; even as hee hath made you the fairest, & moſt accompliſhed: & that he alſo give you the grace, to conſerve me in your moſt deſired favour, that I may be able continually to witneſſe, how violent my affection is towards you.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Heaven grant you may be as faithfull to me, as I am to you; and give you as much quiet and contentment, as you take from me. But what ſhould I ſay more? I muſt ceaſe remembring you of the force and heate of my affection, and entreat you to pitie my martyrdome, and that whereſoever you are, you will bee mindfull of me. And ſo once more, I pray God grant you ſuch proſperities, that your fortunes may parallel your perfections.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Reſt aſſured, ſweet Miſtris, to bee beloved, though not equall to your merit, to whoſe height it is impoſſible my affection can raiſe it ſelfe.

div.head: Queſtions with their anſwers reſolving the doubts of Lovers.
div.p: QVeſt. What is Love?
Anſw. It is the receptacle of penſive mindes, a paſſion that binds the ſpirits.
Queſt. What is the greateſt recompence a woman can make a man?
Anſw. To reveale to him her ſecrets, and make him Lord over her body.
Queſt. How muſt a man behave himſelfe amongst Ladies?
Anſw. He muſt be bold and hardy.
Queſt. Why is Love painted blinde?
Anſw. Becauſe the actions of love cannot be hid or diſſembled.
Queſt. Why be the ſecrets of Love ſo eaſily kept?
Anſw. For the great ſweetneſſe men find in them.
Queſt. Who is moſt ſecret in the ſports of Love?
Anſw. Women, ſince it ſo neerely touches their modeſty.
Queſt. What is the meat of perfect Lovers?
Anſw. Sighes and teares.
Queſt. Why have old men the repulſe of young women?
Anſw. Becauſe they have not wherewith to eaſe them of their griefe.
Queſt. Why doe Lovers wax pale?
Anſw. From the paſſions of the mind.
Queſt. Why doe they picture Cupid with wings?
Anſw. Becauſe the deſires of Lovers doe tend alwayes to high things.
Queſt. Why do Lovers write amorous ſonnets one to another in Rime?
Anſw. Becauſe Poetrie is the friend of Love.
Queſt. Why do women love them moſt dearly that had their maiden heads?
Anſw. Becauſe by the conjunction of the men they gaine perfection.
Queſt. Wherefore are amorous women more tickliſh then others.
Anſw. Becauſe their skins are moſt looſe, ſoft and delicate.
Queſt. How cometh it to paſſe that women newly maried the firſt night are ſo loth to goe to bed, and riſe the next day ſo luſty and joyfull.
Anſw. It proceeds from the perfection of the man, which they having acquired to themſelves, they then know they are women indeed.
Queſt. Why doe men kiſſe the eyes of them they affect?
Anſw. Becauſe they were the firſt beginners of Love.
Queſt. Why doe many love fervently, yet are not beloved againe?
Anſw. By reaſon their complexions cannot agree.
Queſt. Why ſhould wee not place our loves on tho • e that be ſo young?
Anſw. Becauſe they are ſo inconſtant and evermore curious of new ſervants.
Queſt. How comes it that hee that is ſoone taken with love doth ſoone forget it.
Anſw. He is like one who rides a galop, and by and by, waxeth weary.
Queſt. Why do men ſay that Love is a perfect muſitian?
Anſw. Becauſe he tuneth the ſpirits that before had no agreement.
Queſt. What is the greateſt pleaſure that a true lover can feele?
Anſ. To thinke that he is borne to ſerve and pleaſe his Lady.
Queſt. Wherefore be all things more diſpoſed to love in the ſpring time, then in any other ſeaſons?
Anſw. Becauſe then the humours doe move themſelves and the bloud doth wax hot.
Queſt. Wherefore are the Angers of Lovers of ſo little continuance?
Anſw. Becauſe they fall out for trifles.
Queſt. Wherefore doe the Ancients paint Love with flowers in one hand and fiſh in another?
Anſw. To ſhew that Love is Lord both of Sea and Land.
Queſt. Why are men rather Amorous then women?
Anſw. Becauſe they are of hotter complexions, and their ſpirits are more quicke and prompt.
Queſt. Wherefore be all the joyes of Lovers uncertaine?
Anſw. Becauſe in Love are divers caſualties, Iealouſie, ſuſpition, anger, peace, diſdaine.
Queſt. Why is it that ſecret Love is more burning then that which is diſcovered?

Anſw. Becauſe in the one a fire doth conſume
but in the other a friend doth give advice to quench the flames.
Queſt. Whether is more conſtant in Love, the man or the woman?
Anſw. The man being both of body and ſpirit more firme.
Queſt. Wherefore have Lovers feeble voyces?
Anſw. Out of the feare they have to diſpleaſe their Ladies.
Queſt. Wherefore is it that a man being touched with Love cannot rid himſelfe of that paſſion by any dexterity?
Anſw. Becauſe a certaine ſweet motion doth tranſport him to the thing he deſires, and with a certaine admiration winds him into the nets of Love.
Queſt. Wherefore are Lovers for the most part ready to weep?
Anſw. Becauſe by nature they are ſacrefull, ſuſpitious, Iealous and alwaies troubled.
Queſt. Why be women ſo prone to yeeld to Love?
Anſw. Becauſe nature hath indued them with a delicate touch, with complexions hot and moyſt, things moſt requiſite for the recreations of Venus.

div.head: Encomions on the Beauty of his Miſtreſſe.
div.l: FAirer then Iſacks Lover at the well,
Brighter then inſide Barkes of new hewen Cedar;
Sweeter then flames of fire perfumed with Mirrhe,
And comelier then The ſilver Clouds that dance,
On Zephires wings be ore the King of heaven:
Tis ſhe doth teach thoſe Torches to burne bright,
It ſeemes ſhe hangs upon the cheeke of night;
As a rich Iewel in the Ethiopes Eare,
Beauty too rich for uſe, for Love more deare.
So ſhowes a ſnowie Dove trooping with Crowes,
As this my Miſtris, ore her fellowes ſhowes.
Since her whole bodyes frame hath power to have moved,
The chaſt Hippolitus her to have loved.
In ſumme her parts are white as Milke,
As ſmooth as Ivory, and as ſoft as Silke.
O who can her perfections tell
In whom alone all graces dwell?

div.head: On her Haire.
div.l: HEr Haires reflex with red ſtrakes paints the skies,
Stars fall to fetch freſh Luſtre from her eyes.
Whilſt that thoſe golden threds play with her breath,
Shewing lifes triumph in the map of death.

div.head: On her Lockes.
div.l: HEr lockes being plated like a fleece of wooll,
Are full of ſweets, as ſweet of ſweets is full.

div.head: On her forehead.
div.l: HEr ſtately front was figured from above.
Majeſticke faire well poliſht high and pale,
Pure white that dims the Lillies of the Vale.

div.head: On her face.
div.l: HEr face like Cinthiaes when in full ſhe ſhineth,
And bluſhing to her Love mates bowres declineth
Such brightneſſe hath her Angels face,
Can make a ſunne-ſhine in a ſhady place.

div.head: On the colour of her face.
div.l: SVch colour hath her face, as when the Sun,
In Summer his firſt riſing hath begun.

div.head: On her eye-browes and Cheeks.
div.l: EAch eye-brow hangs like Iris in the skies,
On either Cheeke a Roſe and Lilly lyes.

div.head: Another on her eye-browes and breath.
div.l: HEr bright Browes drive the ſunne to clouds beneath,
Sweet morne and evening dew fals from her breath.

div.head: On her eye-Liddes.
div.l: FOr Arches be two heavenly Liddes,
Whoſe winkes each bold attempt forbids.

div.head: On her eyes.
div.l: HEr eyes the contradictors of the night,
Like Marigolds, unſheath their glorious light.

div.head: Another on the ſame.
div.l: TWo Ietty ſparkes where Cupid chaſtly hides,
His ſubtile ſhafts that from his quiver glides.
Piercing the breſts of others yet they be
Vnhappy, ſince themſelves they cannot ſee.

div.head: On her ſmiles.
div.l: HEr ſmiles ſo ſweet and nice,
On earth doe make a heavenly Paradiſe.

div.head: On her Cheekes.
div.l: HEr Cheeks like ripened Lillyes ſteep'd in Wine,
Or gorgeous Clouds upon the ſinnes decline.

div.head: Another on the ſame.
div.l: HEr Cheeks with kindly Claret ſpred,
Aurora-like new out of bed.

div.head: On her Noſe and breath.
div.l: HEr Eagles Noſe is ſtrait of ſtately frame,
Her breath is ſweet perfume of holy flame.

div.head: On her Chin.
div.l: HEr Criſtall chin like to the pureſt white
Is Loves pavilion, and the boyes delight.

div.head: On her Eares.
div.l: ON theſe meanders if you gaze,
You ſoone will tread a Lovers maze.

div.head: On her Lippes.
div.l: HEr lips like Roſes over-waſht with dew,
Doe by her breath their beauties ſtill renew.

div.head: On her Lippes and Necke.
div.l: HEr Lips more red then Corrall ſtone,
Her Necke's more white then aged ſwans that mone.
O who thoſe ruddy lips can miſſe,
Which bleſſed ſtill themſelves doe kiſſe.

div.head: On her mouth.
div.l: SWeet mouth that ſendeſt a muſicke t • ſied breath,
Whoſe every word darts me a living death.

div.head: On her mouth and teeth.
div.l: WIthin the compaſſe of this holow ſweet,
Thoſe orient rankes of ſilver Pearles doe meet.

div.head: On her breath.
div.l: SHe breathes forth flowers, ſhe makes the ſpring,
Perfumes the aire and comforts every thing.

div.head: On her tongue and words.
div.l: HEr words doe fall like ſummer dewes on me,
Her tongue ſtrikes muſicke ſweeteſt harmony.

div.head: On her teeth.
div.l: HEr lips nere part, but that they ſhow,
Of precious pearle a double row.

div.head: On her Speech.
div.l: IN all her words ſuch vertues couched be,
The learned thence fetch their philoſophy.

div.head: On her voice.
div.l: A Voice which doth the thruſhes ſhrilneſſe ſtaine,
And makes declining nature young againe.

div.head: On her Necke.
div.l: HEr Neck is like an Ivory ſhining Tower,
Or like delight that doth it ſelfe devoure.

div.head: On her Shoulders.
div.l: THeſe pearching ſquares with ſilver skin,
Doe paſſe the hate ſpot Ermelin.

div.head: On her Armes.
div.l: HEr Twin-like armes, that ſtaineleſſe paire,
Fit for a Kings embraces are.

div.head: On her Hands.
div.l: HEre azured vaines doe uſe to ſtray,
With pretty Cupids every way,
Moyſt pearle warme ſnow ſmooth Ivory,
Within theſe ſtrange compactes doe lye.

div.head: On her fingers.
div.l: LOng ſmall made fit for Orpheus Lute,
Which made the ſavage tigers mute.

div.head: On her actions.
div.l: HEr deeds are like great cluſters of ripe grapes,
Which load the bunches of the fruitfull Vine:
Offering to fall into each mouth that gapes,
And fill the ſame with ſtore of timely wine.

div.head: On her breaſts.
div.l: HEr breſts thoſe Ivory Globes circled with blew,
Save of their Lord no bearing yoake they knew.

div.head: On her Pappes.
div.l: HEr pappes are like faire Apples in their prime,
And from thoſe ſweets, Love ſuckes his ſummer time.

div.head: On her good thoughts.
div.l: HEr mindfull breſt perfumes wich frankincenſe,
And ſweeteſt odors every fainting ſence.

div.head: On her waſte and Ribbes.
div.l: FItly ſo named ſince it doth waſte,
Mens lives untill it be embrac'd:
Her ribbes with white all armed be,
Compact with curious ſymmetrie.

div.head: On her skin, and fleſh.
div.l: HEr lovely skin is white like Curdes new preſt,
And ſnowie fleſh is ſoft as wooll new dreſt.

div.head: On her Navell.
div.l: HEre Love delights the wandring thought,
Whilſt that mine eyes aſtray are brought:
Since Nature here would faine unite,
In curious circles buſie ſight.

div.head: On her bellie.
div.l: MOſt beauteous ſeale of Virgin wax,
Pittie tis ſtill the impreſſion lackes;
This place my ſence with joy doth fill,
Since tis intitled Cupids hill:
From hence a ſeemely paſſage there doth flow,
To ſtranger pleaſures that are plac'd below.

div.head: On her wombe.
div.l: HEr Maiden wombe the dwelling houſe of pleaſure,
O bleſt is he may ſearch that ſecret treaſure.

div.head: On her thighes.
div.l: THeſe are the ſubjects that doe fit,
The Genius of an Ovids wit,
Whoſe hanches ſmooth as is the glaſſe,
The Albion cliffes in whiteneſſe paſſe.

div.head: On her knees.
div.l: THeſe knots of joy and gems of Love,
With motion makes all graces move.

div.head: On the calves of her legges.
div.l: MArke well how faire the fleſh doth riſe,
In her brave calves like chriſtall skies.

div.head: On the ſmall of her legges.
div.l: VIew but her Atlas ſmalleſt ſmall,
More white then whiteſt bone of all.

div.head: On her feet.
div.l: HEr feet ſo ſhort and ſlender little round,
On earth a finer paire cannot be found.

div.head: The concluſion.
div.l: THus every part impartes a grace,
And beauty dwels in every place.

div.head: Loves mouth.
div.l: MAy is not Loves month, May is full of flowers,
But dropping April, Love is full of ſhowers.

div.head: Definition of Love.
div.l: LOve is a friend, a fire, a heaven, a hell,
Where pleaſure paine and ſad repentance dwell.

div.head: Love will out.
div.l: THe light of hidden fire it ſelfe diſcovers,
And love that is conceal'd betraies poore Lovers.

div.head: The parting of Lovers.
div.l: LOvers well wot what griefe it is to part,
When twixt two bodies liveth but one heart,
And Lovers ſay the heart hath double wrong,
When it is bard the aſſiſtance of the tongue.

div.head: The Inconſtancy of Affections.
div.l: LOve well is ſaid to be, a life in death,
That laughs and weepes, and all but in one breath.

div.head: The quality of Love.
div.l: LOve is a ſpirit all compact of fire,
Not groſſe to ſinke but light, and will aſpire,

div.head: What Love is,
div.l: LOve is a golden bubble full of dreames,
That waking breakes and fils us with extreames.

div.head: Lovers delight to be alone.
div.l: LOvers beſt like to ſee themſelves alone,
Or with their loves if needs they muſt have one.

div.head: Vowes of Lovers.
div.l: WE know not how to love, till love unblind us,
And vowes made ignorantly never bind us.

div.head: Impoſſibility of concealing Love.
div.l: THe ſight of hidden fire it ſelfe diſcovers,
And love that is conceal'd betrayes poore lovers.

div.head: On one ſick with Love.
div.l: VVHen Venus ſtrikes with beauty to the quicke,
Few are the cares for ſuch as are Love ſicke.

div.head: The errors of Lovers.
div.l: ALL men doe erre becauſe that men they be,
And men with beauty blinded cannot ſee.

div.head: What Love is.
div.l: LOve is a ſubtile influence,
Whoſe finall force ſtill hangeth in ſuſpence.

div.head: Love admits of no contrary arguments.
div.l: LOve hates all arguments diſputing ſtill,
For ſence gainſt reaſon with a ſenceleſſe will.

div.head: What Love is.
div.l: LOve is a blinded god, an angry Boy,
A ſlave to beauties will, a witleſſe toy;
A Ravening bird, a tyrant moſt unjuſt,
A private hell, a very Sea of luſt.

div.head: Another definition of Love.
div.l: LOve is a ſoure delight, a ſugred griefe,
A breach of reaſons Law, a ſecret Thiefe,
A living death, an ever dying life,
A Sea of teares, an everlaſting ſtrife:
A bait for fooles, A ſcourge of noble wits,
A deadly wound, a ſhot which ever hits.

div.head: The Effects of Love.
div.l: THis is the leaſt effect of Cupids dart,
To change the mind by wounding of the heart.

div.head: Cruelty of Love.
div.l: LOve is not full of mercy as men ſay,
But deafe and cruell where he meanes to prey.

div.head: The parting of Lovers.
div.l: LOve goes to Love as ſchoole boyes from their books,
But love from love towards Schoole with heavie looks.

div.head: A Maxime.
div.l: TIs folly by our wiſeſt worldlings proved,
If not to gaine by love to be beloved.

div.head: The Conſtancy of Lovers.
div.l: ONce learne to love, the leſſon is but plaine,
And being learnt is never loſt againe.

div.head: The Force of Love.
div.l: WEre beauty under twenty lockes kept faſt,
Yet love breakes through, and picks them all at laſt.

div.head: Of Muſike and Love.
div.l: AS without breath no pipe doth move,
No muſicke's kindly without Love.

div.head: Love finds an opportunity.
div.l: WHen Love hath knit two hearts in perfect unity,
They ſeldome faile to find an opportunity.

div.head: Offers of Love not to be refuſed.
div.l: OCcaſion's winged and ever flyeth faſt,
Comming ſhe ſmiles, and frownes once being paſt.

div.head: Patience of Lovers.
div.l: ONe may indure, for when the paine is paſt,
Reward though long it ſtay yet comes at laſt.

div.head: Sorrowes of Lovers.
div.l: SIghes are the eaſe calamity affords,
Which ſerve for ſpeech when ſorrow wanteth words.

div.head: Teares of Lovers.
div.l: SEld ſpeaketh Love but ſighs his ſecret pains,
Teares are his truch men, words do make him tremble,
Yet womens teares fall when they moſt diſſemble.

div.head: On frozen affection.
div.l: THere where the hearts Atturny once is mute,
The Client breakes, As deſperate of his ſuite.

div.head: Of true and falſe Love.
div.l: TRue Love's a Saint, ſo ſhall you true Love know,
Falſe Love's a Scithian, yet a Saint in ſhow.

div.head: The perſeverance of a Lover.
div.l: DEſire being Pilot and bright beauties prize,
Who can feare ſinking where ſuch treaſure lies?

div.head: The beginnings of Love.
div.l: FAire beauty is the ſparke of hot deſire,
And ſparkes in time will kindle to a fire,

div.head: On Luſt.
div.l: LVſt makes oblivion, beateth reaſon backe,
Forgetteth ſhames pure bluſh and honors wracke.

div.head: On Virginity.
div.l: THe ripeſt Corne dies if it be not reapt,
Beauty alone is loſt too early kept.

div.head: A cruell Miſtris.
div.l: NOthing ſo ill becomes the faire,
As cruelty which yeelds unto no prayer.

div.head: On Coyneſſe.
div.l: A Way-ward beauty doth not fancy move,
A frowne forbids, a ſmile engendreth Love.

div.head: Another.
div.l: FAire words and power attractive beauty,
Brings men to wanton in ſubjective duty.

div.head: On Iealouſie.
div.l: VVHere Iealouſie in baſeſt minds doth dwell,
Tis metall Vulcans Cyclops ſent from hell.

div.head: On pleaſures.
div.l: SOmething muſt ſtill be left to cheare our ſinne,
And give a touch of what ſhould not have bin;
And they that know but pleaſures price,
Alls one, a priſon or a Paradiſe.

div.head: On Chaſtity.
div.l: THe unſtained vaile which Innocents adorne,
The ungatherd roſe defended with the thorne.

div.head: Another on the ſame.
div.l: PEnelope in ſpending chaſte her dayes,
As worthy as Vliſſes was of praiſe.

div.head: On the Court.
div.l: THither let Phoebus ſons reſort,
Where ſhines their Father but in loves great Court?

div.head: On her delaying mariage.
div.l: VVHere hearts be knit what helps if not to injoy;
Delay breeds doubts, no cunning to be coy.

div.head: On Deſires.
div.l: VVHat can be ſaid that Lovers cannot ſay?
Deſire can make a Doctor in a day.

div.head: On Misfortunes.
div.l: THe man that ſtill amidſt misfortunes ſtands,
Is ſorrowes ſlave and bound in laſting bands.

div.head: On fate.
div.l: THey fall which truſt to fortunes ſickle wheele,
But ſtaid by vertue men ſhall never reele.

div.head: On diſdaine.
div.l: IN high diſdaine Love is a baſe deſire,
And Cupids flames doe ſeeme but watry fire.

div.head: On the Power of teares.
div.l: TEares tye the tongue of an accuſers grudge,
And ſoft the rigor of the ſterneſt Iudge.

div.head: On Muſicke.
div.l: MVſicke can hardly ſolace humane eares,
When ſtrings are broke, and eyes are fill'd with teares

div.head: On Continued griefe.
div.l: DRops pierce the flint, not by their force or ſtrength,
But by oft falling weares it out at length.

div.head: On Marriage.
div.l: MAides doe take more delight when they prepare.
And think of wives ſtates then when wives they are.

div.head: On pleaſures and griefes.
div.l: PLeaſures like poſting gueſts make but ſmall ſtay,
Where griefes bide long and leave a ſcore to pay.

div.head: On Youth.
div.l: YOuth learnes to change the courſe that he hath run,
When he perceives and knowes what age hath done.

div.head: On a modeſt faire one.
div.l: BEautie's a beggar, fye it is too bad,
When in it ſelfe ſufficiency is had,
It was not made to pleaſe the wandring eye,
But an attire to adorne ſweet modeſty:
If modeſty and women once doe ſever,
Farewell our fame, farewell our name for ever.

div.head: On his Will.
div.l: IT lies not in my power to love or hate,
For will in me is over-ruld by fate.

div.head: On the loſſe of Virginity.
div.l: IEwels being loſt, we find againe, this never,
Tis loſt but once, and once loſt, loſt for ever.

div.head: On Women.
div.l: LEt Wolves and beaſts be cruell in their kinds,
But women meeke and have relenting minds.

div.head: On coy dames.
div.l: HAte and diſdaine is painted in their eyes,
Deceit and treaſon in their boſome lyes.

div.head: Inconſtancy of women.
div.l: THey melt with words as wax againſt the ſunne,
So weake are many womens modeſties,
That what ſometimes they moſt would ſeeme to ſhield,
Another time poore ſoules unaskt they yeeld.

div.head: Another on the ſame.
div.l: WOmen have tongues of craft and hearts of guile,
They will, they will not, hell is in their ſmile.

div.head: On Luſt.
div.l: LVſt never takes a joy in what is due,
But ſtill leaves knowne delights to ſeeke out new.

div.head: On Virginity.
div.l: LIke untun'd golden ſtrings faire women are,
Which lying long untoucht will harſhly Iar.

div.head: Modeſty of women.
div.l: THough men can cover crimes with their ſterne looks,
Poore womens faces are their owne fault books.

div.head: On a womans teares.
div.l: A Womans teares are falling ſtars at night,
No ſooner ſeene but quickly out of ſight.

div.head: A Conſtant Woman.
div.l: COnſtant in Love who tryes a womans mind,
Wealth, beauty, wit, and all in her doth find.

div.head: Paſſions of a Woman.
div.l: A Womans paſſions doth the fire reſemble,
Never alike, they ſinne if they diſſemble.

div.head: On the finding of Beauty.
div.l: THe faireſt flowers of beauty fades away,
Like the freſh Lillie in the ſunne-ſhine day.

div.head: Another on the ſame.
div.l: FAire flowers that are not gathered in their prime,
Rot and conſume themſelves in little time.

div.head: On the power of Beauty.
div.l: THe Libian Lions looſe their ſterneſt might,
If of a beauteous face they once get ſight.

div.head: Women envie one anothers Beauty.
div.l: IT is a common rule, that women never
Love beauty in their Sexe, but envie it ever.

div.head: On a Beauty cloiſterd up.
div.l: THings much retaind doe make us moſt deſire them,
And beauties ſeldome ſeene make us admire them.

div.head: On Beauty in meane attire.
div.l: IT is decreed that features ſhall content,
And that true beauty needs no ornament.

div.head: On Beauty not injoyed.
div.l: NEver were Cheekes of Roſes, lockes of Amber,
Ordain'd to live impriſoned in a Chamber.

div.head: Beauties for the Court.
div.l: IN vaine our friends from this doe us dehort,
For beauty will be where is moſt reſort.

div.head: Beauties not to be confined.
div.l: HEaven made Beauty like her ſelfe to view,
Not to be lockt up in a ſmoakie mew.
A Roſie tainted feature is heavens gold,
Which all joy for to touch, all to be behold.

div.head: On the excellency and power of Beauty.
div.l: BEauty brings fancy to a dainty feaſt,
And makes a man that elſe would be a beaſt.

div.head: The effects of Beauty.
div.l: BEauty in heaven and earth this grace doth winne,
It ſupples rigor, and it leſſens ſinne.

div.head: A wooing fit in verſe.
div.l: HEE, Much adoe I have god wot,
I would love but thou wilt not.
She, Reaſon, Sir, Men are not true,
HE, Why was any falſe to you,
Sweeteſt I have lov'd thee long;
SHE, Yet Sir Love ſhould doe no wrong.
HE, Prethee ſweet come kiſſe me then,
SHE, No Sir, Maides muſt kiſſe no men.
HE, I the Heavens for witneſſe crave,
SHE, They will ſhine cleere, though you'r a knave.
HE, Never loved a truer youth,
SHE, Men doe not alwayes ſpeake the truth,
HE By all thoſe vowes that Lovers uſe,
SHE, Thus they proteſt yet doe abuſe.
And full oft maides are deluded,
When with kiſſes Love's concluded.

div.head: A diſcourſe of Love in verſe.

sp.speaker: BEL,
sp.l: When will Love be voyd of feares?

sp.speaker: TEL,
sp.l: When Ieaoluſie hath neither eyes nor cares.

sp.speaker: BEL,
sp.l: When is Love moſt malecontent,

sp.speaker: TEL,
sp.l: When Lovers range and beare their bowes unbent.

sp.speaker: BEL,
sp.l: Tell me when Love is beſt fed,

sp.speaker: TEL,
sp.l: When it hath ſuckt the ſweet that eaſe hath bred.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: When is lovers time ill ſpent,

sp.speaker: TEL.
sp.l: When Love doth earne yet takes no rene,

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: When is time well ſpent in Love,

sp.speaker: TEL.
sp.l: When deeds enſue, and words worke Love,

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: What calſt thou Love, I prethee tell,

sp.speaker: TEL.
sp.l: It is a fountaine and that well,
Where pleaſure and repentance dwell.
It is a worke on holy day,
It is December match'd with May.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: I prethee faire one doe not faine.

sp.speaker: TEL.
sp.l: It is a ſun-ſhine mixt with raine,
It is a tooth-ach or like game:
It is a yea, it is a Nay,
A pretty kind of ſporting fray,

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: Come, come, Ile heare no more, away.

div.head: Another ſhort wooing fit in verſe.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: SWeet ſoule to whom I vowed am a ſlave,
Let me the injoyment of my wiſhes have.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Sweet Sir, Let not a wretch that is ſo poore,
Expect to hord up treaſure for his ſtore.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: Yet ſtill take heed leaſt thou thy ſelfe ſubmit,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: To one that hath his wealth, but wants his wit.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: Prethee be ſilent, beauty takes in rent,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But folly bought is worſe then mony ſpent.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: Well for this once, Ile take thee as thou art,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: For richer for poorer agreed, mine owne ſweet heart.

div.head: The feares and reſolutions of two Lovers.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: WHat wouldſt thou wiſh tell me deere lover,

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: How I might but thy thoughts cover.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: If my firme Love, I were denying,
Tell me with ſighes, wouldſt thou be dying?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Thoſe words in jeaſt to heare thee ſpeaking,
For very griefe this heart is breaking.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Yet wouldſt thou change? I prethee tell me,
In ſeeing one that did excell me?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: O no, for how can I aſpire,
To more than to my owne deſire:
This my mishap doth chiefly grieve me,
Though I do ſwear't, you'l not believe me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Imagine that thou doſt not love me,
But ſome beauty that's above me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: To ſuch a thing ſweet doe not will me,
The naming of the ſame will kill me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Forgive me faire one, Love hath feares,

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I doe forgive, witneſſe theſe teares.

div.head: The wooing of a coy Dame.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: THe cauſe my ſweet thou doſt deny,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Becauſe thou doſt not pleaſe my eye.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: Thy reaſon why to me impart,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Thou doſt offend and grieve my heart.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: There is no heart ſo fierce and hard,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Nor perſon of ſo ſmall regard.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: The reaſon, doth thy Love controule,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Thou doſt torment my very ſoule.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: O Remedy my loving ſmart,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ile keepe ſuch danger from my heart.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: Why doſt thou thus thy beauty keepe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: It will deſtroy it, Sir, to weepe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: My paſſions doſt thou mocke at too?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Farewell Sir, without more t • doe.

div.head: A contention betweene a Wife, a Widow, and a Maide.

sp.speaker: WIfe,
sp.l: If to be borne a maid be ſuch a grace,
So was I borne, and grac'd by nature too;
But ſeeking more perfection to embrace,
I did become a Wife, as others doe.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: And if the Maid and Wife ſuch honour have,
I have bin both, and hold a third degree,
Moſt maids are wards, and every Wife a ſlave;
I have my livery ſu'd, and I am free.

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: That is the fault that you have maidens beene,
And were not conſtant to continue ſo,
The fals of Angels did encreaſe their ſin;
In that they did ſo pure a ſtate forgoe.

sp.speaker: WIF.
sp.l: Why marriage is an honourable ſtate,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: And widdow-hood is a reverend degree;

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: But maiden-head that will admit no mate,
Like majeſty it ſelfe muſt ſacred be.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: The wife is miſtris of her family,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Much more the Widdow, for ſhe rules alone:

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: But Miſtris of my own deſires am I:
When you rule others wils, and not your own.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: Only the Wife enjoyes the vertuous pleaſure,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: The Widow can abſtaine from pleaſures knowne,

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.l: But the uncorrupted maid preſerves ſuch meaſure
As being by pleaſures wo'd ſhe cares for none.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: The Wife is as a Diamond richly ſet,

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: The mayd unſet, doth yet more rich appeare;

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: The Widow a Iewel in the Cabinet.
Which though not worne is ſtill eſteem'd as deare.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: The wife doth Love and is beloved againe,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: The Widdow is awakt out of that dreame,

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: The maids white mind hath never ſuch a ſtaine.
No paſſion troubles her cleare vertues ſtream,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Then what's a Virgin? but a fruitleſſe bay,

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.l: And what's a Widdow? But a roſeleſſe bryer,
And what are wives, but wood-bindes which decay,
Yea ſtately Oakes, which by themſelves aſpire.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Wives are as birds in golden cages kept,

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: Yet in thoſe Cages chearefully they ſing,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Widdowes are birds out of thoſe Cages lept,
Whoſe joyfull notes makes all the Forreſtring.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.l: But Maids are birds amidſt the Woods ſecure,
Which never hand could touch nor yet could take,
Nor whiſtle could deceive, nor baite allure,
But free unto themſelves doe muſicke make.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: The Wife is as a Turtle with her mate,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: The widdow as the widdow dove alone,
Whoſe truth ſhines moſt in her forſaken ſtate.

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: The maid a Phenix and is ſtill but one.

sp.speaker: WIFE
sp.l: The wife's a ſoule unto her body tyed,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: The widdow a ſoule departed into bliſſe,

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.l: The mayd an Angell which was ſtellified,
And now to as faire a houſe deſcended is.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: Wives are faire houſes kept and furniſht well,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Widdowes old Caſtles void, but full of ſtate.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But maides are temples where the gods doe dwell.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: An office well ſupplyed is like a wife,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: The widdow like a gainefull office voyd,

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: But maids are like contentment in this life.
Which all the world hath ſought but none injoy'd.

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: Goe wife to Dunmow, and demand thy hire

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Goe gentle mayd, and lead the apes in hell,

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: Goe widdow make ſome yonger brother rich.
And then take thought, and dye, and all is well.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: Alas poore maid, thou haſt no helpe nor ſtay,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Alas poore wife that nothing doſt poſſeſſe,

sp.speaker: MAID,
sp.l: Alas poore widdow, charity doth ſay,
Pittie the widdow and the father eſſe.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: We wives have children, what a joy is this?

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Widdowes have children too, but maids have none,

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.l: No more have Angels, yet they have more bliſſe.
Then ever yet to mortall earth was knowne.

sp.speaker: WIFE,
sp.l: The wife is like a faire manured field,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: The widdow once was ſuch, but now doth reſt,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: The maid like Paradiſe undreſt until'd,
Beares crops of native vertue in her breſt.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Who would not dye a wife as Lucrece did,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Or live a widdow as Penelope,

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.l: Or be a mayd, and ſo be ſtellified,
As all the virtues and the graces be.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Wives are like Apples ſerv'd in golden diſhes,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Widdowes good wine which time maks better much.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But maids are grapes deſir'd by many wiſhes.
But that they grow ſo high as none can touch.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: I have a daughter equals you my girle.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: The daughter doth excell the mother then,
As pearles are better than the mother of pearle.
Maydes loſe their value when they match with men.
A maids the perfect'ſt of created things,
The pureſt gold that ſuffers no Allay,
The ſweeteſt flower that on earths boſome ſprings,
The pearle unbor'd, whoſe price, no pr ce can pay,
The Chriſt all glaſſe that will no venome hold,
The mirror where in Angels love to looke.
Dianaes bathing fountaine cleare and cold.
Beauties freſh roſe, and vertues living booke.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Maids cannot judge becauſe they cannot tell,
What comforts and what joves in marriage be.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Yes, yes, though bleſſed Saints in heaven doe dwell,
They doe the ſoules in Purgatory ſee.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: There never was a wife that like't her lot,

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Nor widdow but was clad in mourning weeds,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Doe what you will, marry, or marry not,
both this eſtate, and that repentance breeds,

sp.speaker: LOver,
sp.l: whilſt thou didſt love me, and that neck of thine
More white and ſoft then Roſes ſilver downe,
Did weare a neck lace of no armes but mine;
I envied not the King of Spaine his Crowne.

sp.speaker: MIST.
sp.l: Whilſt of thy heart, I was ſole Soveraigne,
And thou didſt ſing none but my beauties praiſe;
Which now poore Maid thou doſt ſo much diſdaine,
I envied not the Queene of Englands fame.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What though I ſue to thee again for grace;
And ſing thy praiſes ſweeter than before,
If I within my heart imprint thy face,
Wilt thou love me againe, and love me more?

sp.speaker: MIST.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt be then againe my morning Star,
Though lighter yet then floting Cork thou be;
And then the Iriſh Sea more angry far:
With thee 'Ile wiſh to live and die with thee.

div.head: A Lovers diſcourſe with his heart.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: SHee's cold, thou hot, how can we then agree,

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Not nature now, but Love doth governe me.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: What if her heart be hard, She ſtop her cares,

sp.speaker: H
sp.l: Ile ſigh aloud, and make it ſoft with teares

sp.speaker: L
sp.l: Why then deſpaire, goe pack thee hence away,

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: I live in hope to have a happie day.

div.head: A Diſcourſe betweene a Lover, Death, and Cupid.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Come gentle death. D. who calls?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: ones oppreſt,

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is thy will?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: that thou abridge my woe;
By cutting off my life:

sp.speaker: D:
sp.l: ceaſe thy requeſt,
I cannot kill thee yet,

sp.speaker: L:
sp.l: Alas, Why ſo?

sp.speaker: .D
sp.l: Thou wantſt thy heart.

sp.speaker: L:
sp.l: Who ſtole that ſame away?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Love whom thou ſerv'ſt,

sp.speaker: L:
sp.l: Entreat him if thou may.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Come Cupid, come.

sp.speaker: C:
sp.l: Who calleth me ſo oft,

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Thy Vaſſall true whom thou ſhouldſt know by right,

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What makes thy cry ſo faint?

sp.speaker: L:
sp.l: My vo • ce is ſoft.
Quite broke and ſpent, with crying day and night.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What then, What's thy requeſt?

sp.speaker: L:
sp.l: that thou reſtore,
To me my heart and ſteale the ſame no more.
And thou O death, when I poſſeſſe my heart,
Diſpatch me then at once.

sp.speaker: D:
sp.l: Alas, Why ſo?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: By promiſe thou art bound to end my ſmart.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But if thy heart returne, then what's thy woe?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: That brought from froſt, it never will deſire,
To reſt with me that am more hot then fire.

div.head: Vpon a ſcarfe preſented.
div.l: TAke this ſcarfe, bind Cupid hand and foot,
So love muſt aske you leave before he ſhoot,

div.head: Ʋpon a paire of Siſſers preſented.
div.l: THeſe Siſſers doe your houſe wifery bewray,
You love to worke though you are borne to play.

div.head: Vpon a looking-glaſſe preſented.
div.l: BLind fortune doth not ſee how faire you be,
But gives a glaſſe that you your ſelfe may ſee.

div.head: Vpon a Fanne preſented.
div.l: YOu loue to ſee, and yet to be unſeene,
Take then this Fanne, to be your beauties skreene.

div.head: On a plaine gold Ring preſented,
div.l: FOrtune doth lend you, hap it well or ill,
This plaine gold Ring to wed you to your will.

div.head: Vpon a paire of Bracelets preſented.
div.l: LAdy, your hands are fallen into a ſnare,
For Cupids manacles theſe Bracelets are.

div.head: Complementall and amorous Letters. A Letter to renew affection.
div.l: ALthough I am aſſur'd I cannot dye,
In your remembrance, yet I feare leaſt I
Am like a picture veiled from the light,
And ſo can yeeld no pleaſure to the ſight.
Letters are Cupids Bellowes that doe blow,
Lovers affections, untill they doe grow
Into a flame, theſe doe let Lovers find,
The abſent bodies pleaſures by the mind.
O let me then within your thoughts revive,
And though we are farre diſtant let us ſtrive:
To meet in ſoule, Let love convey me to you,
But in a dreame, that I may ſet and woe you.
Till I doe meet againe by fates direction.
With you the Miſtris of my hearts affection.

div.head: A Letter to perſwade one to be Constant.
div.l: COnſtant Love and vertue are,
In their qualities alike,
Both in darkeſt nights ſhine faire,
Like to ſtars which ſhoot and ſtrike,
Through the skies ſo love will be,
Moſt knowne in ſad adverſity.
Therefore Love, keepe ſtill one minde,
Inſtruct the world how to Love,
Though nature doth new changes find,
Like a center never move,
But while misfortunes doe turne round;
About thee, be thou conſtant found.
Love is like a ſacred flame,
Which quench'd, can hardly be renew'd,
But is evermore the ſame,
